case_title: M/s. STANDARD CHARTERED BANK LIMITED vs MOHAMMAD ALTAF MADRASWALA and another

accussed_details.name: MOHAMMAD ALTAF MADRASWALA
allegation: Default in repayment of house finance loan

accussed_details.name: Another
allegation: Default in repayment of house finance loan

complaint_summary: The plaintiff filed a suit under Section 9 of the Financial Institutions (Recovery of Finances) Ordinance 2001 for recovery of Rs. 5,691,759.62 from the defendants, alleging default in repayment of house finance loan under Diminishing Musharaka agreement.
investigation_summary: Defendants contested the suit, raising legal and factual issues, including unauthorized filing of the plaint, dispute over KIBOR-linked markup, and alleged economic duress in agreement execution.
judgment_summary: The court allowed the application for leave to defend the suit unconditionally, framing issues for determination, including the applicability of KIBOR-linked markup under Islamic finance and the validity of the suit filed by an unauthorized person.
Decision_or_verdict: Application for leave to defend allowed unconditionally; issues framed for further determination.
legal_arguments: Defendants argued that the suit was filed by an unauthorized person without proper authorization documents.
Defendants contested the applicability of KIBOR-linked markup under Diminishing Musharaka agreement, citing State Bank of Pakistan Circular No. 01 of 2004.
Defendants claimed economic duress in agreement execution, rendering it void under Section 83 of the Contract Act, 1872.
Plaintiff argued that the defendants agreed to all terms and conditions, including KIBOR-linked markup, and defaulted on repayment obligations.
assets: Property financed under Diminishing Musharaka agreement
statutes: State Bank of Pakistan Circular No. 01 of 2004
key_issues: Validity of suit filed by unauthorized person
Applicability of KIBOR-linked markup under Islamic finance
Default in repayment of house finance loan
Defendants' rental payments and default status
Liquidated damages dispute over 20% per annum claim

maxims.Economic Duress: An agreement executed under economic duress is void under Section 83 of the Contract Act, 1872.

legal_terms.Diminishing Musharaka: An Islamic finance agreement involving gradual reduction of ownership units.
legal_terms.KIBOR: Karachi Inter Bank Offered Rate, a benchmark interest rate.

words_and_phrases.Economic Coercion: Unlawful pressure exerted to compel agreement execution.
words_and_phrases.Rental Sharing: Distribution of rental value between parties based on ownership shares.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around a dispute over house finance loan repayment under Diminishing Musharaka agreement. Key issues include the validity of the suit filed by an unauthorized person, applicability of KIBOR-linked markup under Islamic finance, alleged economic duress in agreement execution, and rental payments made by defendants. The court allowed the application for leave to defend unconditionally, framing issues for further determination.
